subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Agreed, some objects may have been constructed and some haven t. But what s the problem about freeing resources? ... I see setUp just as a programmatical
messageBody:
On Saturday 28 May 2005 12:36, Cedric Beust wrote:
> Your setUp() method fails halfway, so only half of the resources need
> to be freed.

Agreed, some objects may have been constructed and some haven't.
But what's the problem about freeing resources?

> > The set up belongs to the test. I think it is reasonable to
> > say the test fails if its setup fails.
>
> No, it's not the tests that are failing, it's the setUp.

I see setUp just as a programmatical way to remove duplication, not as a
separate entity.

> Imagine you have 100 tests and 1 set up. The setUp fails, and now
> JUnit is telling you you have "101 FAILURES"... Very helpful!

100 failures, and when I look at the stack trace it's immediately clear
where the problem actually is.

> And QA will freak out on you.

No, they'll never see that -- I don't check in code with failing tests.
(I also assume that QA isn't totally resistant to explanations.)

> Compare this to "1 FAILURE, 100 SKIPS".
>
> Now, *that* is a much more acurate view of what really happened.

As I said, setUp and test method are one in my view of a test results.
But that may be due to I'm used to JUnit's way of handling this.
So, assuming I don't check in code with non-green tests, why is it
important to distinguish between skipped and failed tests?
Doesn't a skip turn the bar red?

Robert
